content.p: Leukocytes play major roles in immunity, with some cells having a larger role in nonspecific immunity (can attack a large range of invaders), while others function in specific immunity (only attack specific invaders). Identify whether each of the following is specific or non-specific.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Neutrophils are non-specific phagocytes, attacking nearly any invader soon after they enter the body's tissues.
Correct. Neutrophils are non-specific phagocytes, attacking nearly any invader soon after they enter the body's tissues.

part.hint: Neutrophils are often the first cells to show up at the site of infection.

response.feedback: Correct. These cells produce antibodies, with each B-lymphocyte producing many copies of the same antibody, which will only bind to one antigen, making it specific.
: Incorrect. These cells produce antibodies, with each B-lymphocyte producing many copies of the same antibody, which will only bind to one antigen, making it specific.

part.hint: Most lymphocytes fall into the same category.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Basophils play important roles in mediating inflammation, which is a nonspecific response to infection or tissue damage..
Correct. Basophils play important roles in mediating inflammation, which is a nonspecific response to infection or tissue damage.

part.hint: Consider the process to which basophils contribute.

response.feedback: Correct. T-lymphocytes often attack virally infected cells (among other functions). But each T lymphocyte will only attack cells displaying a specific antigen tag on it.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Monocytes are nonspecific phagocytes similar to neutrophils, except that they will move into the tissues and mature into large, long-living cells called macrophages, while neutrophils are short-lived cells that only move out of the bloodstream at sites of infections.
